question: Question_02_(d)
sols:
This requires partial fractions. In order to use partial fractions, the
denominator must be factored. One way to find the factors is to find the
zeroes of the denominator, and then use them to create the factors. To
do so we set 3\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}-4\emph{x}+1 = 0. Using the
quadratic formula, we get the following two zeroes:

\begin{align*}\frac{4\pm\sqrt{16-12}}{6} = \frac{4\pm2}{6} = \frac13 \text{ or } 1.\end{align*}

These zeroes can then be put into factors as follows: $(x - 1/3)(x - 1)$

But because the first coefficient of the original denominator is
\emph{3}, we need to multiply these factors by 3, giving:
$3(x - 1/3)(x - 1) = (3x - 1)(x - 1)$

If you're comfortable with factoring, instead of finding the zeroes and
then generating the factors, you can also just factor the denominator
directly.

Now we perform the decomposition into partial fractions:

\begin{align*}\frac2{3x^2-4x+1} = \frac2{(3x-1)(x-1)} = \frac{A}{3x-1} + \frac{B}{x-1}.\end{align*}

When we try to recombine the final pair of fractions, we get:

\begin{align*}\frac{A}{3x-1}\cdot\frac{(x-1)}{(x-1)} + \frac{B}{x-1}\cdot\frac{(3x-1)}{(3x-1)} = \frac{A(x - 1) + B(3x-1)}{(3x-1)(x-1)}\end{align*}

Thus 2 = \emph{A}(\emph{x}-1)+\emph{B}(3\emph{x}-1). An easy way to find
the values for \emph{A} and \emph{B} is to plug in \emph{x = 1} and
\emph{x = 1/3}. Plugging in \emph{x}=1 yields \emph{B}=1 and plugging in
\emph{x}=1/3 yields \emph{A} = -3. We have now decomposed the fraction
as follows:

\begin{align*}\frac2{3x^2-4x+1} = \frac{-3}{3x-1} + \frac1{x-1}\end{align*}

Having now decomposed the expression using partial fractions, we can
return to our original goal, which was to integrate the expression.

\begin{align*}
\int_2^4 \frac2{3x^2-4x+1}\,dx &= \int_2^4 \frac2{(3x-1)(x-1)}\,dx \\
&= \int_2^4 \left(\frac{-3}{3x-1} + \frac1{x-1}\right)\,dx \\
&= \left.\left(\frac{-3}3\ln|3x-1| + \ln|x-1|\right)\right|_2^4 \\
&= -\ln(11)+\ln(3) - (-\ln(5)+\ln(1)) \\
&= -\ln(11)+\ln(3)+\ln(5) = \ln\left(\frac{15}{11}\right).\end{align*}
hints:
The function to be integrated is a rational function. In order to
integrate a rational function, you should factor the denominator and
apply partial fraction decomposition.

Upon applying partial fraction decomposition, we are left with the
expression

\begin{align*}\frac2{3x^2-4x+1} = \frac{-3}{3x-1} + \frac1{x-1}.\end{align*} Now integrate the
right hand side.
